figure_1:
Representative 10 s PIRL-MS
spectra of major pediatric brain cancer
types. The PIRL-MS spectra for ependymoma (EPN) (PF-EPN-A, ST-EPN-RELA),
pilocytic astrocytoma (PA), and medulloblastoma (MB, e.g., Group 4
subgroup) are shown to possess unique mass spectral differentiators.
The mass-to-charge (m/z) values
responsible for 10 s classification of these cancer types whose molecular
identities are determined in this work (see Table 1) are labeled in the black font. The m/z values in the red font represent the
abundant ions over the mass range examined. We have also included
the total ion count for each mass spectrum, suggesting good-quality
mass spectra from these specimens could be obtained under the proposed
experimental conditions. The MB data is previously published6 and is reproduced here for the clarity of discussion
and to ensure that no misclassification of newly analyzed EPN and
PA specimens as MB is taking place.
figure_2:
Sparse Figure S2 PCA-LDA model based
on 18 identified metabolites listed in Table 1. This model is based on a sparse (or low
complexity) PCA-LDA modeling using AMX6,19 that instead
of using the entire m/z 100â€“1000
range worth of m/z features as done
in Figure S2, only utilizes the fully characterized
metabolite array of Table 1. Here, the multivariate model is built only based on simultaneous
dimensionality reduction across only 18 features whose molecular identities
are determined and reported in Table 1. We show two views of the model (rotated around the
LD3, blue axis). LD1 and LD2 axes are shown in red and green, respectively.
figure_3:
Protocol
for supervised two-step classification of major pediatric
brain cancers using PIRL-MS. Through combining findings of this manuscript
with our previous work,6 we propose a two-step
supervised protocol for 10 s classification of 7 types of pediatric
brain cancers. The method uses two 4-component PCA-LDA models deployed
over the cited mass ranges to provide higher than 94% sensitivity
and specificity for pediatric brain-cancer-type classifications. The
first model utilizes well-characterized feature list of only 18 metabolites,
and the second model that takes a deeper dive into molecular subgroups
of medulloblastomas will use a considerably larger number of m/z features some of which currently remain
uncharacterized.
